title: Welcome
text:
Welcome to my new website! I’ve rebuilt this site using Quarto — a modern open-source scientific publishing system. I’ll be using this blog to share updates on my research, teaching, and thoughts on spatial data science.
Stay tuned for more posts.

title: Teaching
text:
I contribute to GEOG0030, UCL’s undergraduate module on geocomputation and spatial analysis using R.

GEOG0030 Coursebook




A collection of R tutorials covering GIS topics including geocoding, network analysis, and greenspace accessibility.

title: Research
text:
My research focuses on transport geography, urban mobility, and spatial data science. I am particularly interested in how spatial analysis and network methods can be applied to understand accessibility, travel behaviour, and urban systems.



Transport and accessibility modelling
Spatial data science and GIS methods
Network analysis of urban systems
Active travel and sustainable transport

title: Jo Wilkin
text:
An avid Geographer, using Geographic Data Science “for good”. Currently a Research Scientist at Tracking California at the Public Health Institute, focusing on spatial analysis and applications for public health and environmental justice across California — from dataset curation and creation to mapping tool development.



Development of a statewide road network dataset detailing Vehicle Miles Traveled for California, including bespoke interpolation methodology deployed in Python
Creation of various R Shiny apps for environmental justice purposes, including the Lithium Valley Data Explorer and soon-to-be published Community Air Quality Monitoring Data Explorer
Development of household-level network Origin-Destination analysis for healthcare accessibility modelling
More spatial analysis work forthcoming




Previously a Lecturer in Geographic (and Social) Data Science at UCL, with teaching focusing on the ethics and politics of (geo-) data science, including the use of large-scale individual-level datasets, as well as principles of spatial analysis.
Doctoral research focused on creating innovative geospatial datasets from Call Detail Records for humanitarian and sustainable development applications, with a focus on social networks and community resilience.
Helped launch The Missing Maps Project in the UK, leading large-scale training and mapathons in London and Southampton. Developed high-quality training material for mapathons, still in use by The Missing Maps to this day. Significant experience in the editing of OpenStreetMap, through both the visual interpretation and digitisation of satellite imagery and the importation of collected GPS tracks and waypoints.
Presented on behalf of The Missing Maps Project at the Royal Geographical Society and Oxford Internet Institute on the role of field data collection and mobile-based data collection apps.
Creator of an award-winning Geography Programming Bootcamp, teaching undergraduates the basic principles of Python programming for data analysis within GIS-based research.
Living in the San Francisco Bay Area since 2016.

title: Jo Wilkin
text:
Experience

Research Scientist (Geospatial) | Tracking California · Public Health Institute

Sep 2021 – Present · San Francisco Bay Area

Lecturer in Social and Geographic Data Science | UCL

Aug 2020 – Sep 2021


Developed and led three modules on Spatial Analysis, Geocomputation and Data, Politics and Society. Geocomputation course delivered via Bookdown website. Teaching GIS programming using R, Python and QGIS across undergraduate and postgraduate programmes. Supervised 5 undergraduate and 3 Masters dissertations.

Teaching Fellow | UCL

Feb 2020 – Aug 2020

PhD Researcher | University of Southampton

Sep 2015 – Feb 2020


Social Connectivity and Disaster Resilience: An Opportunity for Improved Mapping and Measurement using Call Detail Records. Research with the WorldPop group and Flowminder Foundation, supervised by Professor Andrew Tatem and Dr Eloise Biggs. Developed novel methodologies to map geographical communities using CDRs, community detection algorithms, and GIS techniques. Presented at international conferences including NetMob 2019 (University of Oxford) and Geo4Dev 2018 (UC Berkeley).
